instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Hi, have this A1398 with some super weird problems I?ve never seen before. I got it having a short on PPBUS. This was cleared after removing MOSFET Q7260 which cleared the short. Replaced it with a donor and as soon as I gave it power it got very hot and PPBUS was shorted again. I checked out U7201 and found it outputting 12V to a 5V line. Replaced it and the mosfet with another donor and no more short on PPBUS. Still won?t boot though. U7201 has an Enable of 3.02V instead of normal 3.3 but it does have the supply of 12V. Is the low Enable a Problem? Anyone got any tips? Thanks!

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Theonly thing getting a little hot is the PCH

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Welcome to the forum!

Do you really think 3.02V is too low?
If you read many posts, should know that many times we talk about 3V when reffer to 3.3V power rails, or signals.
In fact 2.1V is the min threshold for high logic level (1L); as 0.8V es the max threshold for low logic level (0L).
0.8V-2.1V is a prohibited range, where a logic level is no guaranteed to be recognized correctly.

Burnt U7201 and Q7260 could mean the board is trash now.
Overvoltages on 3V3 and 5V rails is almost letal...
After all, do you get 3V3_S5 and Magsafe light?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Hi, thanks for your reply! 

Yeah, 3.02 should be fine I just wanted to verify. I have a Magsafe Light and PP3V3_S5 is 40mV so basically 0. Any idea on what to do next?

Thanks!

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Post basic voltages for U7201; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Just wanted to measure and my PPBUS is shorted again, 1.2V. No idea why!

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Okay, no my Test charger just quit working


Gonna grab another one and post those voltages

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Use surrounding components as test points.
Do not touch chip pins, if you don't have fine probes!

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
The Voltages are:

Pin 23 - 12.83V
Pin 12 - 3.312V
Pin 13 - 1.5V
Pin 22 - 1.6V
Pin 29 - 1.2V
Pin 21 - 3.1V

Hope my Multimeter didn't slip on any of these....

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: I did. I Always try avoiding to measure at the chip if possible... Remeasured everything, edited the post with all of the updated values

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Are these values of any use for further troubleshooting?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Looks like bad U7201 for me; or incorrect solders.
Post first diode mode (red probe at ground) on pins 13, 22, 29; no power, of course.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
The measurements are:

Pin 13 - .47
Pin 22 - OL
Pin 29 - .45


Should I just order up a new U7201 Chip? I mean we don't fully know if the chip off of the donor board was any good...

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Also check diode mode at L7220/60.
If good, change U7201.

Really strange to got bad one from scrap.
Don't you have more donor boards in the pile?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
It comes up as .39 on L7220 and .002 on L7260, is that of any help?

Sadly completely out of donors

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Short on 3V3_S5, because of burnt Q7260.
Looks like scrap board now.

If have time, you can remove U7201 and Q7260; then check diode mode again.
Do NOT power up the board without U7201...

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Removed both. Now .46 on L7220 and still .002 on L7260. Anything I could theoretically try?


Out of pure curiosity: what would happen if I powered it up with those missing parts?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Also what are nominal Values for L7220 and L7260?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
"Out of pure curiosity: what would happen if I powered it up with those missing parts?"
I could tell you try and see ;).
But I'm afraid you can come and kill me, after lockdown time finished :mad:.
Seriously, do not try any of these options...

Leaving Q7220 with Gate floating on air is a really bad idea.

Remaining short after L7260 could mean damaged SMC, PCH, or CPU.
You can try injecting voltage there and check if something gets hot.
Remove CPU heatsink for test.
Start with 1V and do not exceed 4V; leave amp limit at max on the PSU...

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Ah got ya, just wanted to know. Would never try that... I did find something curious though. On the PCH itself there is a tiny Capacitor. When I put my meter in continuity if beeps on both sides of that cap. On my donor it doesn't. Is that relevant? I'll get a new bench PSU (me idiot killed mine yesterday) and try injecting Volatge

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Beeps is not same as short.
Some power rails have low value as normal; and beeps for this reason.
If you get much higher value on identical board, this is sign of failure.
However, that cap is connected on the same power rails with many other external components; not sufficient reason to doubt about PCH (yet).
Inject voltage and check which component heats...

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Will do once PSU arrives. Also ordered a fresh can of freeze spray.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: BTW where is the best place on that line to inject voltage?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Pin 1 of L7260 is probably the biggest pad.
C7292/93 easy to solder too.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
UPDTAE:

I got my new Bench PSU and after going through a can of freeze spray with a draw of 1A I found C7293 to heat up. Removed it alongside C7292 and now it draws .001A at 1V and the diode mode on L7260 changed to .108

Any better?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Resolder components and check diode mode again; do NOT power yet.
If still low value, Q7260 is probably burnt.
I recommend you to directly change both U7201 and Q7260.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: What do you mean by low value? What is normal?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: With the parts back on the board its .087 on L7260 and .42 on L7220

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
".087 on L7260"
Not too low; I suppose board is not cooled yet.

Did you change mentioned components?
Check diode mode on L7030 too.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Yeah, that could be as with a cold board (room temp) its now .096


I did change the caps but U7201 and Q7260 is the original replacement as I didn't have any and waiting fo china would take ages

L7030 is .486

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
You can try to power up the board now; if all components are back in place.
But I recommend you to follow exact steps mentioned bellow for "power sequence" ;).
Cross the fingers, pray and pray more; finally connect charger.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: Oof. more issues! No fan spin or anything. But then I noticed a big fat burn mark on R6920. Replaced it but now the green light comes on for about 5 seconds before turning off and with freeze spray I can see R6902 immediately heating up. Any idea?

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Just skipped quickly through this thread, but why are you putting time and effort into a board that had 12V on the 5V rail? Not want to rain on your parade, but the chance of a dead PCH/CPU is pretty much 100% here. 

R6920 getting hot will be a short on 3V42 or on the input of U6990. I'm going for 3V42 short that traces back to the PCH.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
Yeah. Probably financially an absolute waste of time. But I just wanna get this fixed no matter what. Yeah I?m weird.


Replaced U6990 but that helped nothing. Any way I can find out if the PCH is actually bad? I mean if I knew it was I?d replace it but I?m not sure if it is...

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: is 3V42 shorted? If yes inject 3V into that rail and see if PCH heats up. If it does then you should really stop there as there is probably even more damage beyond the PCH too.

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: It heats up a bit, yeah... Should I order a new PCH from AliExpress or get one from a donor board and attempt a replacement? Never replaced a PCH before though I did a CPU upgrade on an 09 white MacBooms so it shouldn't be much dirfferent...

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message: I bet you have more damage than PCH only...

threads.title: 820-3332-A A1398 weird power problems
threads.message:
0.76mm or 0.45mm balls, that is the difference. You can order it new or get it from a dead board, but you maybe it will be better to fix the dead board you are pulling it from than this thing.

Seriously, this will be a total waste of time and money, this thing is done.
